title: Add support for hiding interfaces, services, streams and updates from documentation.
body:
This PR adds a `#[hidden]` attribute for use within the `interface! { ... }` macro.

It is exposed as a new field on the different introspection types.

Sadly that makes it a breaking change, because it's adding a new public field to the structs.

title: Add documentation.
body:
This PR adds an asciidoc document that can be compiled as html

Below you can find an example of the rendered html:

title: revert back to v0.6.0
body:
I am unable to release fizyr_rpc, without being made a repo owner :(

 Luckily, I realized that we don't actually need the unreleased changes yet (I am using `Arc::ptr_eq` instead of `same_peer` now).  This commit is just so that the repo reflects the current state of the published crate.

I suggest that we leave it at `0.6.0` for the time being.

title: Same channel check
body:
Quick guys, while Maarten is gone let's change everything.

I am implementing `fizyr-rpc-mi` and we need a way to check whether or not two 'Clients' are equivalent so that we can properly handle an `unsubscribe` request.  This seemed safer than exposing the underlying channel as `pub`

title: Use generic associated types for splitting transports.
Remove thiserror dependency
body:
This pull request removes the thiserror dependency and replaces it with a hand written impl of Error, Display and From traits.

[Corresponding Jira ticket](https://fizyr.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/FS/boards/13?modal=detail&selectedIssue=FS-807&quickFilter=72)

title: Make Transports decide which errors are fatal.
body:
This PR makes the `Transport` implementations decide which errors are fatal. The exact rules for when a transport is or is not usable anymore depend on the underlying socket type.

For now, almost all errors remain fatal, to avoid ending up with situations where we continue to use an unusable socket. However, making this change now allows us to change the behavior later without breaking backwards compatibility (the `Transport` trait is public).

title: Provide transport info
body:
This PR makes information about the connection available to users of the crate.


It is not possible to retrieve this information through a `PeerHandle`, primarily because the `PeerHandle` has no idea which underlying transport is used. However, you can get the information from a `Transport` and from a `Peer` (through `peer.transport()`) before the `Peer` is spawned.

Additionally, functions that directly create a `PeerHandle` without exposing the `Transport` also provide you with the info object. This means `Peer::connect()`, `Listener::accept()` and `Listener::run()`.

For TCP connections, the information includes a local and remote socket address.

For connection oriented Unix sockets (stream and seqpacket), the information includes a UID, GID and PID. I did not add a local or remote address for these, since connected Unix sockets have no address.

title: Add RecvMessageError::is_connection_aborted and request_handle[_mut].
Rename crate::util::format module to crate::format.
Add wireshark dissector for TCP and UDP transports.
Add interface introspection.
body:
This PR adds introspection for generated interfaces.

It uses the serialization format (`F`) to get type information for message bodies. This allows different formats to serialize the same type differently. It also decouples this from the work in fizyr-binary, which is important, because `fizyr-binary` is not (currently) open source.

And even if it was, it's not nice to tie this to a single serialization format.

As usual, it may be best to read the different commits one. I tried to keep them neatly organized.

title: use single vectored write instead of header and body
Generate interface specific format traits.
body:
This PR generates an interface specific format trait.

The idea is that you can use the trait to write generic user code without spelling out insanely long trait bounds for each message type that the format has to be able to encode/decode.

/edit: It may be easier to look at the commits one by one, since the first one only shuffles stuff around.

title: Give access to unknown/invalid messages in generated interfaces.
body:
This PR adjusts the API of generated interfaces to allow peers to handle invalid messages more flexibly, by giving access to the request handle for unknown/invalid request messages, and to the message for unknown/invalid stream/update messages.

If parsing was attempted, the body has been consumed, so only the message header is available.

title: Unlink sockets before binding them.
body: Also moved the changelog to the new format. Let me know if the messages are correct :+1:

title: Use constant instead of magic number.
body: I was hoping to remove [this](https://github.com/fizyr/fizyr-rpc/blob/main/src/error.rs#L136) magic number as well, but I don't see how. One option is to depend on [enum-unitary](https://crates.io/crates/enum-unitary), another is to reference `MessageType::Stream`, as it is the last element in the enum. Both are not exactly ideal. One adds a dependency, the other is an error waiting to happen (though it is unlikely additional types will be added frequently, if ever).

title: Suppress clippy::ptr_arg for generated functions.
body:
Generated functions that send messages take a reference to the body. If that body is `Vec` or `String` or a similar type, clippy gives a warning that you should take a slice or `str` instead.

It would be great if we could actually magically adjust the types when when sending, but there is no generic way to do that that I know of.

So this PR simply turns of the warning.

title: No generated module
body:
This PR removes the module generated by the `interface!(...)` macro. Often, you will need to define message bodies outside of the `interface!(...)` macro, and those will not be in the same module.

That can be solved by making the module private and then re-exporting the contents with `pub use foo::*`, but then the documentation on the module is lost.

Instead, with this PR all items are generated in the same module where the macro is used, and an `Interface` struct is added for introspection. The introspection now only exposes the interface documentation, but in the future it will also have a list of services and streaming messages.

title: Make handles clonable regardless of Format parameter and add tests.
body: `#[derive(Clone)]` is too picky when it comes to generic parameters that don't need to be cloned. So instead we use a manual clone implementation, and add some tests to guarantee that the handles can be clones regardless of the generic parameters.

title: Implement `Clone` for the write handles of generated interfaces.
Totally rework errors and support remote errors in generated interfaces.
body:
This PR completely changes the way errors are reported to users.

They're now an opaque error type with some public constructors and accessors. This may look less nice than it was before, but it hugely simplifies maintaining the crate since we can more easily change the `InnerError` without breaking backwards compatibility. It also hugely reduced the number of unique error types, which also helps with maintenance.

The error rework was done to add support for remote errors in generated interfaces, which is also part of this PR.
